questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found in a confused state at a rest area along an interstate highway in Florida. She is unable to recall her name, address, or any other information regarding her person. She denies being the woman on the Connecticut driver's license found in her wallet.  A telephone call with the police department of her hometown reveals that she had been reported missing three days ago by her husband. When the husband arrives, he reports that his wife has had a great deal of stress at work lately and that before she went missing, she was anxious about telling her boss that she will not meet the deadline for her current project. She has had two major depressive episodes within the past 4 years that were treated with citalopram. She drinks one to two beers daily and sometimes more on weekends. She does not use illicit drugs. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical and neurological examinations show no abnormalities. On mental status examination, she is oriented only to time and place but not to person. Short-term memory is intact; she does not recognize her husband or recall important life events. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Depersonalization disorder does not usually cause gaps in memory. Instead, it is characterized by feeling detached with respect to one's own thoughts, feelings, body, and actions, which is not the case in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Memory impairment is the most prominent finding in major neurocognitive disorder (dementia). However, early-onset dementia in a 28-year-old patient is extremely unlikely, as early-onset dementia mostly affects people in the fifth and sixth decade of life. In addition, this patient's memory loss and impairment of spatial-temporal awareness seem to be only of episodic character and the patient is lacking other typical findings of major neurocognitive disorder, such as speech difficulty and difficulty with reasoning.

C) INCORRECT:

Dissociative identity disorder can result in the inability to recall personal information or events of daily life. Wandering or purposeful travel of which the patient has no recollection is a possible feature of dissociative identity disorder that is seen in this patient. The diagnosis of dissociative identity disorder requires the presence of at least two distinct personality states that cause identity disruption and dominate at different times. As there are no signs of this in this patient at this point, dissociative personality disorder would not be the right diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Korsakoff syndrome causes selective amnesia, which can be both anterograde and retrograde. However, Korsakoff syndrome develops as a consequence of long-term thiamine deficiency, which typically occurs in individuals with alcohol use disorder. Even though this patient does consume alcohol on a regular basis, her examination shows no signs of thiamine deficiency (e.g., ataxia, nystagmus, apathy, indifference, confabulation).

E) CORRECT:

This patient's inability to recall autobiographical information after a stressful event at work raises suspicion for dissociative amnesia. Since this patient's episode of dissociative amnesia involved traveling away from her usual surroundings, the specifier “dissociative fugue” applies. The diagnosis is further supported by the significant social impairment associated with her symptoms and the absence of a physiological (e.g., traumatic brain injury, transient global amnesia), psychiatric (e.g., dissociative identity disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder), or substance-related (e.g., alcohol use disorder, medication adverse effects) cause for her presentation.

F) INCORRECT:

Delirium is an acute disorder that can also cause deficits in memory and confusion. Delirium can be triggered by many factors, including psychoactive drugs, such as citalopram, which this patient had been taking. However, the patient is lacking all other typical findings of delirium, such as illusions, hallucinations, or reversal of the sleep-wake cycle.
questions.hint: This patient's disorder is often connected to a stressful or traumatic event.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician accompanied by his roommate because of recurrent memory gaps and angry outbursts. When an episode occurs, he cannot recall what has happened for several hours. Twice, his roommate encountered the patient timidly huddled up on the floor while “talking to the others” in an unusually high-pitched child-like voice. The patient vigorously denies any memory of the situation. He recently lost his job at the zoo because of his sudden behavioral changes. When he was 3 years old, his father died in a train crash. His mother had obsessive-compulsive disorder and severely punished him whenever he would get something dirty as a child. He does not smoke or take illicit drugs, but drinks several beers every weekend that “help him drown his feelings of not being part of this world”. He has taken multiple psychiatric drugs for depression and anxiety in the past, which did not help improve his symptoms. The patient is meticulously shaved and excessively well-groomed. He appears calm and confident. Physical examination shows old scars over his wrists. On mental status examination, short-term memory is intact. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Schizophrenia is characterized by recurring (or chronic) episodes of psychosis, which may be characterized by behavioral changes. This patient's conversations with invisible people could suggest auditory hallucinations, a schizophrenia-defining symptom. However, to establish the diagnosis, at least one other symptom of the following would have to be present: delusions, disorganized speech, grossly disorganized/catatonic behavior, or negative symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Dissociative amnesia is characterized by memory gaps that lead to clinically significant social and/or occupational impairment. Although this patient has experienced frequent lapses in memory and recent job loss, his other symptoms (angry outbursts, possible auditory hallucinations) are better explained by another psychiatric disorder, which, by definition, excludes dissociative amnesia as a diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

Dissociative identity disorder (DID) is characterized by the disruption of identity into at least two distinct personality states in combination with recurrent memory gaps. In addition to these two criteria, a diagnosis of DID requires that the symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment and that the symptoms must not be related to substance use, other medical conditions, or be part of an accepted cultural or religious practice. This patient's sudden behavioral changes (child-like behavior, angry outbursts, calm and confident behavior at time of visit) are suggestive of separate identity states. Moreover, his recurrent episodes of amnesia, recent loss of employment, and behavioral changes that are not limited to his weekend alcohol use further support the diagnosis of DID. Further manifestations of DID present in this patient include episodes of derealization (“feelings of not being part of this world”) and auditory hallucinations (suggested by the patient “talking to the others”). A history of abuse or neglect during childhood is present in about 90% of patients with DID.

Although patients with DID are commonly portrayed in movies as abusive or harmful towards others, they are rather more susceptible to self-harm and suicide.

D) INCORRECT:

Depersonalization disorder is characterized by a feeling of detachment from oneself. Affected individuals often describe this feeling as observing themselves from outside their bodies. This patient, however, describes a feeling of “not being part of this world”, which is more consistent with derealization than depersonalization. In derealization, individuals feel detached from the external environment. Finally, neither depersonalization nor derealization disorder is associated with memory gaps or sudden changes in behavior.

E) INCORRECT:

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) can develop in response to experiencing a traumatic event (e.g., child abuse), which is evidenced here from this patient's history. However, other symptoms of PTSD such as distressed mood, altered reactivity (e.g., sleep disturbances), avoidance of triggering stimuli, and intrusive symptoms (e.g., flashbacks, nightmares) are not seen here. Moreover, this patient's amnestic episodes and sudden behavioral changes with no apparent trigger are inconsistent with PTSD.

F) INCORRECT:

Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is characterized by emotional instability and a lack of impulse control that can result in frequent angry outbursts, which are seen in this patient. In addition, individuals affected by BPD often display self-destructive behavior, as suggested by the scars across this patient's wrists. However, BPD is characterized by the inability to maintain interpersonal relationships combined with a high fear of abandonment, which is not expressed by this patient. Moreover, his amnestic episodes and sudden behavioral changes are inconsistent with BPD.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of abuse during childhood presents with sudden behavioral changes (child-like behavior, angry outbursts, calm and confident behavior at time of visit) and recurrent gaps in the recall of daily events, both of which are characteristic of his condition.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman is brought to clinic by her husband because she is responding only to the name “Jenny” when her name is actually Diane. In the clinic, she speaks with the cadences and tone of a young child, holds a teddy bear, and sucks her thumb. One year ago, she came to the clinic with a similar presentation.
Her husband reports that she has had short periods of mildly depressed mood, but she has never had psychiatric treatment. She has no known history of substance use or other medical illnesses. She has a documented history of sexual abuse during childhood. Her daughter recently left home for her freshman year of college.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Functional neurologic symptom disorder is characterized by neurologic symptoms, such as paralysis or blindness, without a neurologic or medical basis; it is linked to a psychological reaction and is not feigned or explained by a substance or culture.

B) INCORRECT:

Post-traumatic stress disorder develops after a person directly experiences or witnesses a severe trauma or learns of a loved one’s exposure to such a trauma. Patients experience intrusive symptoms (e.g., intrusive memories, dreams, or flashbacks) and avoid stimuli associated with the trauma. Symptoms include changes in mood and cognition, as well as increased arousal or hypervigilance.

C) CORRECT:

Dissociative identity disorder (previously known as multiple personality disorder) is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of childhood trauma who undergoes an acute change in personality. This disorder is characterized by the presence of two or more distinct personality states that alternate and control an individual’s behavior.

Key learning point: The presence of two or more distinct personality states that alternate and control a patient’s behavior is indicative of dissociative identity disorder.

D) INCORRECT:

People with somatic symptom disorder have one or more distressing somatic complaints that cause them significant distress or that significantly disrupt their daily functioning. Symptoms may or may not be related to another medical condition. Patients with this disorder have an unusual level of anxiety about medical illness. They experience their symptoms as unduly threatening and spend excessive time and energy on their health concerns.

E) INCORRECT:

Dissociative amnesia with dissociative fugue is a dissociative disorder that often involves wandering or unplanned travel, combined with deficits in one’s sense of identity and recall of the past; it may be so drastic that patients do not remember fundamental personal, social, and occupational data.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college student arrives in the emergency department by ambulance, after campus security guards found her wandering around in a confused state.
The patient recalls walking to her apartment after leaving a campus party the night before but remembers nothing beyond that point. She has abrasions on the extensor surfaces of her arms and medial thighs. Further physical examination reveals abrasions and bruising of the labia minora. There is no evidence of head trauma.
The patient is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. She is calm and organized in her thought process, with no cognitive deficits on mental status examination.
Serum and urine drug test results are negative, and imaging studies are also unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to explain this patient’s presentation of episodic memory loss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) develops after a person directly experiences or witnesses a severe trauma or learns of a loved one’s exposure to such a trauma. Complete amnesia for an event or block of time is not a hallmark of the diagnosis, although a patient with PTSD may forget some details of a traumatic event. The core features of PTSD include intrusive symptoms (e.g., intrusive memories, dreams, or flashbacks), avoidance of stimuli associated with a trauma, changes in mood and cognition, and increased arousal or hypervigilance. By definition, symptoms must last at least one month.

B) INCORRECT:

Transient global amnesia is a syndrome characterized by several hours of profound memory loss and disorientation; it usually occurs in middle-aged or older adults, and its etiology is unclear.

C) CORRECT:

In the setting of a possible traumatic experience, and without a known toxic, metabolic, or other neurologic cause, it is most likely that the patient's memory loss is due to a psychogenic cause. The most likely diagnosis in this case is dissociative amnesia, which is characterized by an inability to recall autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature. This type of memory loss generally does not involve retrograde amnesia nor do patients have trouble learning new information. The memory loss cannot be better attributed to the physiologic effects of a substance or another medical condition.

This patient has evidence of sexual assault on physical examination, and should be managed accordingly with testing and prophylaxis for pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections, and consideration of involvement of law enforcement.

Key learning point: A common dissociative disorder that is defined as one or more episodes of inability to recall important personal information of a traumatic or stressful nature, restricted to the period following the trauma, and not accompanied by problems learning new information is dissociative amnesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the presence of psychotic symptoms for at least one day but less than one month. The psychosis may or may not be associated with a significant stressor.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional neurologic symptom disorder is the presence of unfeigned motor or sensory deficits that cannot be explained by a medical or neurologic disorder.

When an episode occurs, he cannot recall what has happened for several hours. Twice, his roommate encountered the patient timidly huddled up on the floor while “talking to the others” in an unusually high-pitched child-like voice. C) CORRECT:

Dissociative identity disorder (DID) is characterized by the disruption of identity into at least two distinct personality states in combination with recurrent memory gaps. Although patients with DID are commonly portrayed in movies as abusive or harmful towards others, they are rather more susceptible to self-harm and suicide.

In addition, individuals affected by BPD often display self-destructive behavior, as suggested by the scars across this patient's wrists. However, BPD is characterized by the inability to maintain interpersonal relationships combined with a high fear of abandonment, which is not expressed by this patient. Moreover, his amnestic episodes and sudden behavioral changes are inconsistent with BPD.
questions.hint: This patient with a history of abuse during childhood presents with sudden behavioral changes (child-like behavior, angry outbursts, calm and confident behavior at time of visit) and recurrent gaps in the recall of daily events, both of which are characteristic of his condition.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female college student arrives in the emergency department by ambulance, after campus security guards found her wandering around in a confused state. The patient recalls walking to her apartment after leaving a campus party the night before but remembers nothing beyond that point. Physical examination reveals abrasions and bruising of the labia minora and medial thighs. There is no evidence of head trauma. The patient is alert and fully oriented, with no cognitive deficits on mental status examination. Serum and urine drug test results are negative, and imaging studies are also unremarkable. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely to explain this patient’s presentation of episodic memory loss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) develops after a person directly experiences or witnesses a severe trauma or learns of a loved one’s exposure to such a trauma. Complete amnesia for an event or block of time is not a hallmark of the diagnosis, although a patient with PTSD may forget some details of a traumatic event. The core features of PTSD include intrusive symptoms (e.g., intrusive memories, dreams, or flashbacks), avoidance of stimuli associated with a trauma, changes in mood and cognition, and increased arousal or hypervigilance. By definition, symptoms must last at least one month.

B) INCORRECT:

Transient global amnesia is a syndrome characterized by several hours of profound memory loss and disorientation; it usually occurs in middle-aged or older adults, and its etiology is unclear.

C) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this case is dissociative amnesia, which is characterized by an inability to recall autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature. This type of memory loss generally does not involve retrograde amnesia nor do patients have trouble learning new information. The memory loss cannot be better attributed to the physiologic effects of a substance or another medical condition.

This patient has evidence of sexual assault on physical examination, and should be managed accordingly with testing and prophylaxis for pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections, and consideration of involvement of law enforcement.

Key learning point: A common dissociative disorder that is defined as one or more episodes of inability to recall important personal information of a traumatic or stressful nature, restricted to the period following the trauma, and not accompanied by problems learning new information is dissociative amnesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the presence of psychotic symptoms for at least one day but less than one month. The psychosis may or may not be associated with a significant stressor.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional neurologic symptom disorder is the presence of unfeigned motor or sensory deficits that cannot be explained by a medical or neurologic disorder.
questions.hint: In the setting of a possible traumatic experience, and without a known toxic, metabolic, or other neurologic cause, it is most likely that the patient's memory loss is due to a psychogenic cause.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after being found wandering aimlessly in a park. He appears detached with a blank stare and does not recall his name or how he arrived at the park. Earlier that day, he received news that his best friend died unexpectedly. He has no prior psychiatric history and denies any substance use. On examination, he is cooperative but unable to answer personal questions about his identity.
Which defense mechanism best explains his presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Denial involves refusing to acknowledge distressing realities, often by minimizing their impact. The patient's inability to recall personal details and his dissociation from identity are not characteristic of denial, which does not typically involve memory disruption or identity confusion.

B) CORRECT:

The patient's sudden amnesia regarding his identity and aimless wandering following a traumatic event are indicative of dissociation. This defense mechanism involves an involuntary disruption in the integration of consciousness, memory, and identity, allowing the individual to escape overwhelming psychological pain. The emotional distress from his friend's unexpected death likely triggered this transient disconnection from his personal identity and surroundings, characteristic of dissociative phenomena such as dissociative amnesia with fugue elements.

Key learning point: Dissociation is a defense mechanism where an individual disconnects from their thoughts, feelings, or sense of identity, often in response to trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Suppression involves a conscious effort to set aside distressing thoughts while remaining aware of them. The patient's inability to recall his identity and his blank stare suggest an involuntary, unconscious disconnection, consistent with dissociation rather than a deliberate choice to avoid distressing information.

D) INCORRECT:

Regression involves reverting to earlier, childlike behaviors under stress, such as seeking comfort or exhibiting dependency. The patient's detachment from identity and aimless wandering are more consistent with dissociation, which involves disruption of personal identity and memory, rather than a return to immature behaviors.

questions.text: You are seeing a 19-year-old female college student who was brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being found wandering in a confused state by campus security. She recalls walking to her apartment after leaving a campus party the previous night but does not remember anything after that. On physical examination, there are abrasions and bruising of the labia minora and medial thighs. There is no evidence of head trauma. She is alert and fully oriented, and her mental status examination shows no cognitive deficits. Serum and urine drug tests are negative, and imaging studies are unremarkable. Which one of the following diagnoses most likely explains her episodic memory loss?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the presence of psychotic symptoms for at least one day but less than one month. The psychosis may or may not be associated with a significant stressor.

B) INCORRECT:

Transient global amnesia is a syndrome characterized by several hours of profound memory loss and disorientation; it usually occurs in middle-aged or older adults, and its etiology is unclear.

C) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this case is dissociative amnesia, which is characterized by an inability to recall autobiographical information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature. This type of memory loss generally does not involve retrograde amnesia nor do patients have trouble learning new information. The memory loss cannot be better attributed to the physiologic effects of a substance or another medical condition.

This patient has evidence of sexual assault on physical examination, and should be managed accordingly with testing and prophylaxis for pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections, and consideration of involvement of law enforcement.

Key learning point: A common dissociative disorder that is defined as one or more episodes of inability to recall important personal information of a traumatic or stressful nature, restricted to the period following the trauma, and not accompanied by problems learning new information is dissociative amnesia.

D) INCORRECT:

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) develops after a person directly experiences or witnesses a severe trauma or learns of a loved one’s exposure to such a trauma. Complete amnesia for an event or block of time is not a hallmark of the diagnosis, although a patient with PTSD may forget some details of a traumatic event. The core features of PTSD include intrusive symptoms (e.g., intrusive memories, dreams, or flashbacks), avoidance of stimuli associated with a trauma, changes in mood and cognition, and increased arousal or hypervigilance. By definition, symptoms must last at least one month.

E) INCORRECT:

Functional neurologic symptom disorder is the presence of unfeigned motor or sensory deficits that cannot be explained by a medical or neurologic disorder.
